But not everyone's here to score.
For some, the victory is in just showing up.
You get the shut-in geeks - video gamers who've come out to the bar for their one night a week, you know, for their excuse to come out to a bar and then there's other beautiful girls out here.

Michael McFadden emcee's Rock Band Night at Whitlows.

He says the crowds have definitely gotten bigger.
For proof, I've turned to Jonathan Williams, who runs the bar.
He says the $400 it cost to buy the Xbox totally paid off, because it gets people to stay in his bar.
Put it to you this way - if you and I are hanging out in here, and we get here at 9 o'clock and drink a couple of beers, by 10 o'clock, we might consider getting up there on stage.
And by 11 o'clock, you know for sure we're going to be rocking, you know, playing air guitar.
And for the gamers more new to navigating the happy hour jungle, there's a lesson in common courtesy.
I don't know how much you drink when you play Rock Band at home, but here you've got to tip your server.
The Xbox requires no tips and that plays on until last call.
Leslie Unrue(ph) is in charge here.
She had an abortion as a young woman and has been an outspoken abortion opponent ever since.
A dozen years ago, she bought one of the city's two abortion clinics and turned it into a pregnancy counseling center.
She says she doesn't care if the law ever reaches the Supreme Court.
I simply try to do what's right by women in South Dakota.
And she says it doesn't matter to her that the one remaining clinic in the state only performs about 800 abortions a year.
People say only 800, but to me, that's 800 women.
That's 800 unborn women.
You know, that's children.
Unrue also disputes the way her opponents describe the law, especially its lack of exceptions.

It's not a ban, because there is the life of the mother exception and there is a provision for a woman to go to her own doctor and to take emergency contraception or whatever kind of medicine you want if it is a situation where you have been raped.
Across town at the Empire Mall, a random sample of shoppers finds most have already made up their mind.
Outside the Old Navy store, Sandy Vanderhewl(ph) of Yangdon says she wants the ban overturned.
I'm going to vote against it because I just feel it's very strict and I don't think there should be an abortion ban at all in the first place.
While over in the food court, Arthur Darnell of Huron is just as firmly on the other side.
I support the law as our legislators have already approved it.
No exceptions.
Polls show about 10 percent haven't made up their mind and those are the voters both sides are targeting.
People like Donna Dibvig(ph) of Sioux Falls.
I'm definitely pro-life, but I'm struggling with my decision.
I really am.
Dibvig says she's troubled by the law's lack of exceptions but also by the possible reverberations beyond the state.
I know South Dakota, if this passes, will be making a precedent for the nation.
Clearly, that's what Roger Hunt hopes.
He's a member of the state legislature and one of the law's sponsors.
He says at least part of the motivation for the law is to challenge Roe v.
Wade in light of the two new Supreme Court justices appointed by President Bush.
Given some decisions made by the U.S.
Supreme Court the latter part of '05 and early '06, it would indicate that there's some rethinking going on on the U.S.
Supreme Court.
But something happened to the law on the way to Washington.
South Dakota abortion rights advocates decided to gather signatures to force a statewide referendum rather than file a lawsuit.
Sarah Stoesz is executive director of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota and North and South Dakota, which performs the state's only abortions.
She says having the referendum serves a larger purpose.
People for the first time in South Dakota are sitting across their kitchen tables and they're really talking about abortion.
They have to.
So they're asking one another under what circumstances they might allow it, and how would they feel if it was their daughter, and what about rape and incest, for example?
And Stoesz says no matter which way the vote goes, the clinic will continue to provide abortions - at least for now.
If voters decide to keep the ban, Planned Parenthood will then file the lawsuit the law's sponsors always expected.
Julie Rovner, NPR News.
North Carolina prisoners who say they've been wrongly convicted will soon have an avenue outside of the court system to pursue their claim.
The state this week created the nation's first Innocence Inquiry Commission.
Former North Carolina Chief Justice I.
Beverly Lake, Jr. spearheaded the effort to create the innocence panel.
He joins us on the line.
Hello, there.
Thanks for speaking with us.
Mr.
I.
BEVERLY LAKE, JR. (Former Chief Justice, North Carolina): Hello.
Thank you for having me.
Justice Lake, I imagine a judge's biggest fear is sending the wrong person to prison.
Was there something you saw from the bench that led you to start working on this?
Well, yes, there were, Debbie.
Actually back in 2002, we had several high profile wrongful convictions come to light by means of the press.
The press brought enough pressure so they had another hearing, and they were determined to be innocent.
That's what prompted me to start the study commission.
Explain to us how this Innocence Inquiry Commission is going to work.
Well, it will be an independent commission of eight members.
We will have a trial judge presiding.
We will have a prosecutor, a defense attorney, a sheriff, a victim advocate, and two at-large members appointed by the governor.
So it's an eight-member commission.
And the convicted person will have to prove his innocence by way of new information or new evidence that was not considered by the jury.
And if the case merits a further review, it's then referred to a three-judge panel.
And then if they determine unanimously that the person was wrongly convicted, he will be exonerated.
Justice Lake, how common are wrongful convictions?
They're very infrequent.
We had, as I said, about four or five very high profile cases that came to light several years ago.
We've had, I think, one since that time.
The problem with the ones that came to light was that the people had been in prison for many, many years.
So one almost 19 years before DNA proved that he was the wrong person.
And DNA also found the actual perpetrator.
What is the most common reason innocent people are convicted?
Surprisingly, the most common reason, almost 80 percent, of wrongful convictions result from faulty eyewitness identification.
It frequently proves to be inaccurate.
Now, why is it that the courts don't catch these things?
I mean, why do you need a separate panel?
